objinfo.numberleaves: 1On the verso is a sketch by Blake, commonly known as "The Infant Hercules Throttling the Serpents" (c. 1793).

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington
provenance.note: The early history of the manuscript is not known. According to Butlin, it came into the possession of Dante Gabriel Rossetti by 1868 (253). Before his death in 1919, Rossetti’s brother, William Michael Rossetti, gave the manuscript to Leonard Erskine Hill. His wife, Janet Alexander Hill, acquired the manuscript (perhaps as a gift) no later than September 1931. In 1933, it was offered for sale by the dealer James Rimell & Son (catalogue 288, item 64) along with Blake’s pencil drawing Queen Katharine, Awakening from Her Dream, after Fuseli for £225. The manuscript and the drawing Queen Katharine were then offered by the dealer A. C. Stonehill in July 1937. Lessing J. Rosenwald acquired the manuscript no later than 1939 and gave it to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, in 1943.

repository.addressline: Constitution Ave. NW, between 3rd and 9th Streets

lg.l: A Fairy leapt upon my knee
I said Tho[u] thing of patches rings
Weeping he fell upon my thigh
And thus in tears did soft reply
Knowest thou not O Fairies Lord
How much by us Contemnd Abhorrd
Whatever [ ][d][ ] [t]he Female form [note on darker strokes?]
That cannot b[]a[] the Mental Storm
Our lives to make the Female live [note stray mark(?) above live?]
And what would turn into Disease
We turn to what will joy & [P/Pl]lease
